title: Looking for a script similar to "Memoirs of a Geisha" movie logo
content:
My wife is trying to identify the font used for the word Geisha in this picture. If you know the name of it please let me know.

Thanks

the misfit

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211im_/http:/typophile.com/files/n125954_5839.jpg)
author: themisfit

comments.content: I’ll put it out there; it’s possible that this is custom brush lettering. I could be wrong (and if I am, we’ll find out soon.)
Most probably hand lettered indeed. What would we need all those talented calligraphers for?

If you want something similar, try [Escrita](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/escrita/?refby=typographica) or [Gizmo](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.veer.com/partner/link.aspx?i=1048&c=4&p=products/typedetail.aspx?image=GTT0000006).

There’s also a freebie called “Bambino” that’s in the ballpark. (Babe Ruth reference intentional)...  
DB~
You could also contact [Jill Bell](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.art.net/Studios/Visual/Jillbell/Intro.html) who has talent literally coming out of her ears.
Dennis, I’m pretty sure that freebie is actually a knock-off of [Bergell](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/bergell/).

[Rob Leuschke](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=Leuschke) has some very nice brush scripts that could easily substitute for this, which I agree looks hand-drawn.

- Mike Yanega

Miss Tiffany- As usual, you’re right! I had never seen Bergell before... A knock-off by any other name is still a knock-off!  
DB~
Hand-drawn, and with a proper pen I suspect. Interesting that here in Canada, the DVD is marketed with a comparatively boring serif....

Though he didn’t do the title for _Memoirs of a Geisha_, Seattle based [Tim Girvin](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.girvin.com/port/exp/film.htm) is well known and established for handlettering and calligraphy used in films, branding, logos, etc.  
 [
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211im_/http:/typophile.com/files/girvin_matrix_5624.jpg)
](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.girvin.com/port/ind/ent_clients/matrix.shtml)  
For some reason his name rarely appears on Typophile.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211im_/http:/typophile.com/files/girvin_skycaptain_5217.jpg)
  
Here’s an [interesting interview](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/seattle.bizjournals.com/seattle/stories/2006/05/08/story8.html?i=44077) he gave regarding his work for film industry.
That logo for The Matrix proves Weingart’s theory that a good designer can make a beautiful design with a lousy typeface.

Agreed, Yves.  
And to paraphrase another saying, _There are no bad typefaces, just bad uses_.
Thanks for all th help. I am looking for a asian inspired script font. Do you know where I could find something like that?

Ruth Rowland represented by illustration created the hand lettering in question.Here is a link to website.

[http://www.illustrationweb.com/RuthRowland/](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.illustrationweb.com/RuthRowland/ "http://www.illustrationweb.com/RuthRowland/")

<cite>Hand-drawn, and with a proper pen I suspect. Interesting that here in Canada, the DVD is marketed with a comparatively boring serif….</cite>

The hand-drawn title and lips image was for the book, different design with serif used for the film. By chance I have an invite to the UK premiere and party at Nobu in front of me...

... in Trajan (of course).

[http://www.thefilmfactory.co.uk/geisha/](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.thefilmfactory.co.uk/geisha/ "http://www.thefilmfactory.co.uk/geisha/")

\> _There are no bad typefaces, just bad uses._

I beg to differ, my esteemed colleague. There are intrinsically bad typefaces, quite a few of them even. ;^)
[Mockingbird](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=GF.112208.0.0)

\> _There are no bad typefaces, just bad uses_.

I must admit there have been some typefaces that made my brain hurt, and could quite possibly cause a stroke in the weak of heart.

\> _There ARE bad typefaces, and bad sayings as well_ ;^)

[Nick Cooke](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Nick%252BCooke)’s [Gizmo](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=GTT0000006) perfectly fits the bill, Carson.

_“I am looking for a asian inspired script font. Do you know where I could find something like that?”_

My suggestion would be [Kendo](http://web.archive.org/web/20091222050211/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/itc-kendo/), by the late Phill Grimshaw.

- Mike Yanega

In fact, there are several scripts by Grimshaw and his friend Timothy Donaldson, which could easily be taken for Asian inkbrush or pen calligraphy: Banshee, Flight, Humana Script, John Handy, Riptide, Ru’ach, Ulysses (Donaldson); Grimshaw Hand, Pristina and Samuel (Grimshaw).

(Sorry for not taking time to make links for each of these. They are at most large vendors)

- Mike Yanega
